On September 25, the cost appears as $1: "WALT. WHITMAN'S POEMS—'LEAVES OF GRASS'—for sale to dealers and retail. Single copies, $1. FOWLER & WELLS, No. 308 Broadway." An October 15 ad omits the period after "Walt" (though it appears again in later ads): "WALT WHITMAN'S POEMS—'LEAVES OF GRASS'—for sale to dealers and retail. Single copies, $1. FOWLER & WELLS, No. 308 Broadway." On November 23, the paper copies are added: "WALT WHITMAN'S POEMS—'LEAVES OF GRASS'—for sale wholesale and retail. Single copies, $1; paper, 75Â¢. FOWLER & WELLS, 308 Broadway." These "paper" copies were probably part of a third consignment to Fowler & Wells and taken from a set of 46 copies in "boards mounted" Whitman had ordered from the binder in July 1855; according to the binder's statement, he did not have another 150 copies bound in paper until December 1855. At the top of Whitman's anonymously published review in the October 1855 American Phrenological Journal, "An English and an American Poet," the price of Leaves of Grass is listed as $1.25. The book was advertised in the London Publisher's Circular and Booksellers' Record of British and Foreign Literature on October 15, 1855 for 6s. 6d. (6 shillings, sixpence).No author's name is associated with the volume. It is listed as "LEAVES of Grass. With Portrait of Author. 4to. (Brooklyn, New York), pp. 96, cl. London, 6s. 6d." Stern writes that Fowler & Wells continued to advertise the book until March 1856, despite lackluster sales, though no ads appeared in the Tribune from November 24, 1855, until February 18, 1856. An ad in the February 18 issue that ran until early March read: "WALT. WHITMAN'S POEMS.—'LEAVES OF GRASS,'—This work was not stereotyped; a few copies only remain for sale, after which it will be out of print."New York Tribune, 18 February 1856; Stern, 110. Citing a "Notes and Queries" ad in Life Illustrated, Myerson notes that "As late as 14 June 1856, Fowler and Wells were selling copies in cloth for $1.25 and in wrappers for 75Â¢" (18).

The first edition of Leaves of Grass met with a great deal of criticism, but several reviewers spoke with admiration of Whitman's style, his imagery, or his use of language. Allen, attributing to Whitman's journalistic network the surprising amount of attention this privately published volume received by reviewers, writes that "Nearly everyone saw in it the influence of Emerson or transcendentalism, or both."Solitary Singer, 173. This reaction might have been in part a product of who was reading the book and how it was circulating: a list of original owners of surviving copies, compiled from the census data, suggests that a large percentage of identifiable owners were close associates and friends of Emerson. Reputed admirers would range from Conway, who had read Leaves of Grass at Emerson's encouragement, to Abraham Lincoln.Allen, Solitary Singer, 175 and 170.

div1.head: VI. Emerson's letter and the reviews and extracts
div1.p: One of the notable early admirers of Leaves of Grass was Ralph Waldo Emerson himself. In October 1855, some three months after receiving Emerson's laudatory letter, Whitman worked with Charles Dana, then managing editor of the New York Tribune, to print the letter in that paper.In an 1888 conversation with Traubel, Whitman described the conversation that led to the appearance of the letter in the Tribune: "I met Dana one day: he had heard of the letter: asked me to let him have it, use it . . . . I objected when he said, 'why not? You might just as well—in fact I think you ought'" ("Sunday, November 18, 1888" [3:125]). As Allen points out, the hesitancy Whitman describes himself as having in this account is somewhat suspect (Solitary Singer, 173–74). A version of the story appears in Bucke's Walt Whitman: "[The Emerson] letter was eventually published (at first refused by Walt Whitman, but on second and pressing application he consented), at the request of Chas. A. Dana . . . . Walt Whitman has since been censured for printing a so-called private communication of opinion, not intended for the public. In answer to this, besides no proof that the letter was meant to be private, the editor of the 'Tribune,' who was a personal friend of both Walt Whitman and Mr. Emerson, would probably have been a judge in such matters, and he sought it for the columns of his paper, as legitimate and proper to both parties" (139). Whitman also at some point evidently decided to arrange for the independent printing of slips with Emerson's letter with the words "Copy for the convenience of private reading only" at the top. The Tribune clipping or one of the printed slips is pasted into several surviving copies of the 1855 Leaves of Grass. Allen has noted that the newspaper clipping or the printed slip with the Emerson letter may have been purposefully pasted into copies sent to noted authors and journals: examples include Longfellow, whose copy is now at Harvard University.Solitary Singer, 173. For Longfellow's copy, which includes the Tribune clipping, see HU_04. Another example may have been that of John Forster, English biographer and friend of Charles Dickens, whose copy includes the printed version of the Emerson letter. The Forster copy is now at the Victoria & Albert Museum (see VAM_01). The note at the top of the printed slip has been marked through in pencil in several of the copies; in at least one, it has been cut off entirely.See UVa_09 and WC_02, respectively (scans of both are visible in the image comparison viewer). If indeed Whitman was responsible for inserting the letters in the copies, it is unclear why he would have had the printer include this note, only to cross it out. Perhaps his original intention in printing the slips was to circulate them independently of the copies, or perhaps there was a more elaborate advertising strategy at work.

Whitman also arranged for the printing of an eight-page insertion of reviews and extracts from reviews and critical essays, which was bound into several copies of the 1855 Leaves. Three of the reviews he had written himself and published anonymously in periodicals.Whitman's composition of his own reviews was noted critically by reviewers; see the Albion review discussed in Folsom, "A Previously Unknown," and also The New York Daily Times, 13 November 1856: 2. Allen, noting the comparatively loose standards of practice for book reviewing at the time, suggests that Whitman "was probably encouraged by the editors to write the reviews" (Solitary Singer, 171). Whitman himself noted the precedents for self-reviewing in an annotation written next to a clipped paragraph from the article "Autobiography of Leigh Hunt," originally published in the January 1851 issue of The American Whig Review. Next to the paragraph, having underlined "This method of commenting upon one's own productions is not altogether unauthorized," Whitman noted "Leigh Hunt criticizing his own poems—Also the same sort of self-criticism by other poets—." Below the paragraph, he wrote: "Spenser criticized himself" ("The Prelude," Walt Whitman Papers [MS 162, Volume 163], David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University). One extract was taken from an 1844 North American Review article, credited to E. P. Whipple, reviewing Rufus W. Griswold's Poets and Poetry of America—the same Griswold whose unsigned November 1855 review excoriated Leaves of Grass as a "mass of stupid filth."Rufus Wilmot Griswold (1815–1857) was an editor, journalist, and critic who became Edgar Allan Poe's literary executor and infamously attacked him in an obituary and a memoir published after Poe's death. Poets and Poetry of America was a respected anthology that helped to build Griswold's reputation. Whitman excerpted a very small portion of Whipple's lengthy essay to include in the 1855 insertion. A copy of the 1855 Leaves of Grass with the note "R. W. Griswold, from the author," written on the front free endpaper in an unidentified hand, is now at the University of Virginia (UVa_10). Remarkably, Whitman also included Griswold's review in the insertion.The Criterion review was unsigned, and Whitman did not associate Griswold's name with it in the 1855 insertion, so it is unclear whether or not he knew who had written the review. Another excerpted essay, credited to the London Eclectic Review, was originally a review of Sydney Yendys's The Roman: A Dramatic Poem.The review actually appeared in the June 1850 issue, though it was dated July 1850 in the 1855 insertion. Whitman almost certainly encountered the review as a reprint in the August 1850 issue of Harper's Magazine, which featured the (new) title "Have Great Poets Become Impossible?" Whitman adopted this title in the insertion. A brief final paragraph in the insertion, printed with another excerpt under the heading "Extracts from Letters and Reviews," was part of a longer spiritualist essay about life after death.This essay was published as "Death—As Said to be Described by One Who Has Experienced It" in the 1857 British Spiritual Telegraph with the note "From the Family Herald." Whitman must have encountered an earlier version of it, but it is not yet known whether the version he read was from the Family Herald or somewhere else. Both excerpts under the "Extracts from Letters and Reviews" heading were taken from essays, so it is unclear why Whitman added "Letters." Perhaps at one point he had intended to include the Emerson letter in the insertion. He would go on to print both the Emerson letter and several of the reviews as part of the "Leaves-Droppings" section of the 1856 Leaves of Grass.

The reviews and extracts insertion was probably printed after Griswold's review appeared on November 10, 1855.There is, of course, the possibility that Whitman had a copy of the text of Griswold's review before it appeared in the Criterion. But the tenor of the review would make that a little surprising. It must have been completed by January 1856, when the last set of cloth bindings were done.The majority of the reviews in known surviving copies appear in copies with binding B (green cloth with blind-embossed ornaments). Two appear in copies with binding C (paper or boards, although the binding on the copy with boards that includes the reviews likely has been repaired, and the boards probably are not original). See Winship, Myerson, and Bibliography of American Literature records. As Eric Conrad has pointed out, this reviews insertion "clearly anticipated the pre-planned 'Leaves-Dropping' annex of the 1856 edition."Conrad, "Introduction." Several of the reviews also were included in the 1860 pamphlet Leaves of Grass Imprints, produced and promoted by Thayer and Eldridge, publishers of the 1860 Leaves of Grass.For more about the publication and circulation of Imprints, see Conrad, "Introduction." It is worth noting that the three items from the 1855 Leaves insertion that did not appear in either Imprints or "Leaves-Droppings" were the three essays unrelated to Leaves of Grass (the extracts from Whipple's essay, the London Eclectic review of Yendys, and the brief final paragraph of the insertion, possibly taken from the Family Herald). In "Leaves-Droppings," Whitman also omitted one of his own reviews ("Walt Whitman and His Poems") and Griswold's Criterion review, although he did include the Griswold review in Imprints. For more on Whitman and promotion, see Conrad, "The Walt Whitman Brand," and Blake. See also Blalock, "Early Draft Advertisements." One brief extract, included in the 1855 insertion under the "Extracts from Letters and Reviews" heading, was taken from a Christian Spiritualist review, from which Whitman would publish longer excerpts in both the 1856 Leaves of Grass and Imprints (1860).Interestingly, Whitman chose a slightly different selection for the 1855 insertion. This was one of several reviews in Imprints whose listed date in that pamphlet did not match the date of their original publication.

For the reviews Whitman wrote, comparing the versions bound into the 1855 Leaves with their original published versions in periodicals reveals some interesting differences. Some of these reflect the same kind of close attention to the representation of the physical body of the author evidenced in the alterations to the frontispiece engraving. To Whitman's "Walt Whitman, A Brooklyn Boy," for instance, was added a footnote that had not appeared in the original version of the review when it was published in the September 18, 1855, issue of the Brooklyn Daily Times. The footnote was the catalog of "Phrenological Notes" about Whitman that had been given to him by Fowler in 1849. The notes brought into the review of Whitman's works a distinctly physical vision of the poet, much like the frontispiece had. "This man has a grand physical constitution," the notes read: "He is undoubtedly descended from the soundest and hardiest stock." "[M]arkedly among his combinations" are listed "the dangerous faults of Indolence" and "a certain reckless swing of animal will, too unmindful, probably, of the convictions of others."

Between the periodical and 1855 insertion versions of this review, too, Whitman or a printer shaved off five pounds from the author: the Brooklyn Daily Times version reads "weight a hundred and eighty-five pounds," while the insertion version reads "weight a hundred and eighty pounds."It is tempting to speculate that the Brooklyn Daily Times, like any camera, may have added five pounds—but the "hundred and eighty five" also appeared in a proof version of the review, so the five pounds were removed between the proof and the 1855 insertion. Whether Whitman (or a printer) did so out of concern for space or vanity is anyone's guess. In a notation written at the front of a scrapbook, Whitman listed his weight "at Hoboken" as 187 pounds in July 1852; in a notation just below that, he lists it "at Crystal Palace" as 179 pounds (corrected from 177) (Feinberg, 85 and 88; the scrapbook is now digitized as part of the Charles E. Feinberg Collection at the Library of Congress). By the 1856 "Leaves-Droppings" and Imprints, the review had dropped the mention of weight altogether, although the age was kept, freezing the author in time if not in space: "age thirty-six years, (1855)."Leaves of Grass (1856), 361. Perhaps this was because the physical description of the poet had moved into the poetry, necessitating a separation from markers of time and age. The author in the 1855 review, "Of pure American breed, of reckless health, his body perfect, free from taint from top to toe, free forever from headache and dyspepsia, full-blooded, six feet high, a good feeder . . . . ample limbed, weight a hundred and eighty pounds, age thirty six years (1855)" appeared now in "Broad-Axe Poem" (1856) as the last of several representative American figures: "Of pure American breed, of reckless health, his body perfect, free from taint from top to toe, free forever from headache and dyspepsia, clean-breathed, / Ample-limbed, a good feeder, weight a hundred and eighty pounds, full-blooded, six feet high, forty inches round the breast and back."Leaves of Grass (1856), 158–59.

Users of the variorum will no doubt notice other significant changes between the original periodical and the 1855 insertion versions of the reviews. To facilitate analysis, we have provided links (using the Juxta collation platform) to comparison views of the three reviews that Whitman wrote, highlighting differences between the periodical versions and the 1855 versions. We have only included links to Juxta comparisons for the reviews written by Whitman for two reasons. First, it is unclear which original periodical version Whitman was working from for some of the reviews and essays he did not write. In the case of the London Eclectic Review article, for instance, Whitman included that source note even though he almost certainly was reading the Harper's Magazine version (which includes a title that matches the one used in the 1855 insertion). Second, when we were able to compare the original version of a non-Whitman-authored review to the version that appears in the 1855 insertion, alterations were minimal. Mostly these consist of minor changes to punctuation or the omission of quoted passages. Notable differences include the considerable and sometimes unmarked omissions from Whipple's essay (the sections Whitman included represent a small proportion of that essay) and the London Eclectic Review essay, as well as, perhaps, a revision from "gross obscenity" to "obscenity" in the second to last paragraph of Griswold's review.The sentence appears in the Criterion as: "Thus, then, we leave this gathering of muck to the laws which, certainly, if they fulfil their intent, must have power to suppress such gross obscenity." It is unclear whether this revision was purposeful or done by Whitman—and even if it were, the change may have been based on spatial rather than semantic considerations. The use of "obscenity" rather than "gross obscenity" is retained in Imprints.

Some surviving copies of the 1855 Leaves of Grass also include a proof stage of one or more of the reviews Whitman wrote. At least two proof sheets also exist of the extracts from a September 1855 Putnam's Monthly review, unsigned in the original but written by Charles Eliot Norton, which Whitman included in the insertion.See PU_02 and UVa_09. In the case of the Whitman-authored reviews, these sheets, typically laid into the front or back of copies, feature some differences from both the periodical and the final, eight-page 1855 insertion versions of the text.The only substantive difference between the proof and the 1855 insertion version of the extracts from Norton's review is the missing date on the proof. For more about Norton's review and tentative support of Whitman's work, see Buckingham. Because there are few substantive differences that are unique to the proofs, which is to say that appear neither in the periodical versions nor in the eight-page insertion versions, we have not treated these proofs separately in the variorum.Like the differences in the non-Whitman-authored reviews, the differences in the proofs tend to be punctuation differences. The proofs are a middle stage between the periodical versions and the 1855 insertion versions: they feature some changes that were made to the 1855 insertion versions of the reviews, but in other ways are consistent with the earlier periodical versions. It is worth noting, however, that the proof of "Walt Whitman, A Brooklyn Boy" does not yet include the phrenological note by Fowler, suggesting that the note was a comparatively late-stage addition.

If language from the reviews made it into Whitman's poems in later editions of Leaves of Grass, as in the case of "Broad-Axe Poem," the language of the 1855 Leaves of Grass was also used in the reviews. Several of the reviews Whitman wrote include language quoted and in some cases adapted from the preface and the poems. We have not attempted to note these related passages and quotations in the variorum, other than retaining the original layout when the poetic lines cited in the reviews are set off from the surrounding text as quotations. In particular, the section of the preface that is included in the review titled "Walt Whitman and his Poems"—beginning "the essences of American things" and continuing to the end of that paragraph—is not marked as quoted text, and it features some substantive revisions from (or, perhaps, toward) the text of the preface.In the opening part of the quotation, for instance, compare "the essences of the real things and past and present events" in the preface (iv) to "the essences of American things, and past and present events" in the review. This line (and much of this section of the preface) became part of "Poem of Many in One" in the 1856 edition of Leaves of Grass, and there it reads "Surrounding the essences of real things, old times and present times" (Leaves of Grass [1856], 185).

div1.head: VII. Copies and later histories
div1.p: In an 1888 conversation with Whitman, Traubel asked: "So you do not know what became of the first edition?" "It is a mystery," the poet responded, "the books scattered, somehow, somewhere, God knows, to the four corners of the earth: I only know that they never have been in my possession.""Friday, October 12, 1888" (2:472). As the century wore on and Whitman's popularity increased, the first edition became both expensive and difficult to find.In an 1889 conversation with Traubel, Whitman described (perhaps with some embellishment) both his own and Bucke's efforts to locate and purchase a first edition: "'Years ago I made every effort to get some copies—secured high and low, but with no result. I think Doctor has one—scoured one after three or four years of persistent agitation everywhere in the bookstores.' Here he paused. 'But I must not be positive about that: it may have been another book. Some of them turned up in London—a few: I wish I had half a dozen: where can they have gone?" ("Friday, February 15, 1889" [4:152]). In other comments later that year, he seemed amused and skeptical at the high price of the books and questioned the intentions of those who wanted to buy them: "Tom [Harned] had spoken of getting—or trying to get—a first edition. W. appealed: 'Tell him not to—tell him it's not worth while—not worth the powder. I don't know what a fellow can want with it—it costs 20 dollars—I think that is the price. If Bucke got one for less—I think he did—he got it at a discount. Yes, yes—tell Tom not to. It is held at a ridiculous figure. Why, I should think a fellow would want the last book—the last edition—the full edition—complete'" ("Wednesday, September 18, 1889" [6:4]). Whitman did keep a copy of the 1855 Leaves of Grass in a paper wrapper, in which he made notes and collected manuscripts, and which Traubel located after the poet's death. See Barney, "Whitman's Copy." In his 1871 volume Notes on Walt Whitman, John Burroughs concluded his account of the publication and sale of the first edition with the note that "At the present day, a curious person poring over the second-hand book-stalls in side places of northern cities, may light upon a copy of this quarto, for which the stall-keeper will ask him, at least, treble its first price" (19). Burroughs was in earnest, it would seem. An 1877 Boston bill of sale inserted in a copy of Leaves now held in a private collection reported the cost of the transaction as $5.The sale was by Boston booksellers A. Williams & Co. to Mr. B. E. Perry. See PC_12. And a century and a half later, that price would have been a steal, even accounting for inflation. As of January 2018, seven copies of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass were offered for sale on AbeBooks.com with listed prices ranging from $45,000 to $270,000.

The books that make up the first edition, different from one another even at the point of production, have become more so over time as the result of use. A series of owners over the course of the ensuing one hundred and fifty years annotated or hand-corrected the copies, pasted bookplates into them, inserted other materials into them, gave them to friends or family members, and in at least one case used them for a purpose quite unrelated to the content of the volume. The Whitman Archive's bibliography of copies, generated and updated from Folsom's 2005 census data and linked from the variorum, provides descriptions and known provenance information for approximately two hundred surviving copies of the 1855 Leaves of Grass now in public and private collections around the world.

The annotations in the surviving copies of the 1855 Leaves suggest a range of responses to the book, covering a long history of reading. A penciled annotation in one copy responds sarcastically to the following lines with the word "modest?":
Divine am I inside and out, and I make holy whatever I touch or am
touched from;
The scent of these arm-pits is aroma finer than prayer,
This head is more than churches or bibles or creeds. Many other copies have markings next to particular lines. Richard Maurice Bucke marked a typo in a copy given to him by Whitman in October 1890, joining several other readers who noted the same error.This may have been a small act of revenge: Whitman vigorously rewrote the early drafts he was sent of Bucke's 1883 biography Walt Whitman. At least two other readers also noted the misspelled "adobe" (spelled as "abode") in "Song of Myself" (BrU_02 and UTA_02). The error does not seem to have been corrected (in print) in copies of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, but it is changed to "adobe" in the 1856 edition. In later editions, Whitman spells the word "adobie." Owners pasted in bookplates and letters, signed their names on the flyleaves, and occasionally wrote notes about the provenance of the books.Information about these notations and insertions concerning the various owners of the books is available in the bibliography of copies. Whitman himself autographed and dated several copies. Bucke's copy, for instance, is signed by Whitman on the title page.See LC_11. The inscription reads: "Walt Whitman / Camden, New Jersey / Oct: 31 1890." Several of the copies signed by Whitman are dated in the 1880s and 1890s. See, for instance, UTA_03 (dated August 3, 1884) and UVa_09 (dated February 12, 1882). Archivists' and booksellers' notes and repository stamps also frequently appear on the endpapers and flyleaves of the books.

If some of the annotations situate the books within a narrative of provenance, others situate them within a broader context of reception. One lengthy series of notes written on the front endpaper of one Library of Congress copy concocts a (mostly false) reception narrative. In pencil is written: "Emerson was asked his opinion of this book—'What a pity,' he said 'that a man with the brain of a God should have the snout[?] of a hog'—Wendell Phillips turned over page after page & said—Here are all sorts of leaves except fig-leaves!" A second owner, reader, or responder wrote below this note: "If this is true then Wendell Phillips has no regret—but Emerson— —" A printed newspaper extract with an 1887 letter from Alfred Tennyson to Whitman is pasted on the same page.See LC_12.

Other kinds of material were inserted into the books as well. A copy owned by W. L. Tiffany has the imprint of a pressed leaf on page 81.See LC_01. The Library of Congress copy with the invented reception narrative includes a photograph of the English actress Ellen Terry, taken by a London photographer.Ellen Terry (1847–1928) was a member of Henry Irving's company, famous for her appearances in Shakespeare plays. In the 1880s, Whitman sent to Terry (via Bram Stoker) a collection of poems, perhaps the 1872 pamphlet As a Strong Bird on Pinions Free and Other Poems or Two Rivulets (1876). See Terry's letter to Whitman dated January 4, 1888. In one copy now at the University of Virginia, a reader inserted a newspaper article about female mill workers stopping their work to watch "the boys of Manayunk" bathing in the Schuylkill. The article was placed in the book next to the segment of "Song of Myself" about the "twenty-ninth bather." The headline reads: "Bathing in River Stopped Running of Mr. Ball's Mill: Operatives So Interested That They All Flocked to the Windows."See UVa_09. The article is not dated.

Some owners pasted or inserted other works by Whitman into their copies of the 1855 Leaves. A clipping of Whitman's poem "A Death-Sonnet for Custer" is pasted on the front endpaper of the University of Iowa copy used as the base text for the variorum. A copy of Whitman's "Bardic Symbols," published in the Atlantic Monthly in 1860, was tipped into a copy of the 1855 Leaves now held at Williams College.See WC_01. In an extreme example, an owner of one of the copies now held at the Huntington Library took advantage of the unusual size of the book and turned it into a scrapbook, cutting out pages and pasting over the rest with non-Whitman-related poetry and articles clipped from newspapers.
Figure. A page from a copy of the 1855 Leaves of Grass (HL_01) that was converted into a scrapbook. Image courtesy the Huntington Library, Art Collections, and Botanical Gardens.
And the copies reflect other reactions of readers to the poetry, including some of Whitman's more controversial lines. One copy at Texas Tech University shows the results of the reader expurgating juicy passages with a pen.
Figure. Page of a copy of the 1855 Leaves of Grass (TTU_01) showing a reader's expurgations. Texas Tech University.

At least one partial copy of the 1855 Leaves has circulated piecemeal. Individual leaves of a "leaf copy" were bound and sold separately by Bennett Book Company in 1930. Printed on the title page included with each leaf are the words: "One precious leaf from the first edition / Leaves of Grass / by Walt Whitman / Who assisted in Setting the Type, Supervised the Press Work, and Lent a Hand in Binding This Book of His Life. / Privately Arranged for 47 Lovers of Whitman / New York, 1930."See PC_20. "Leaf-books" of this kind were not uncommon in the cash-strapped depression years, as book publishers scrambled to stay afloat, sometimes by catering to collectors with specialty projects. Michael Winship writes of leaf-books that "this practice seems to have particularly flourished during 1920s and 1930s: it is a way to turn an incomplete copy of a famous book into something sellable. Of course for very rare or very expensive books, this is the only way that most collectors will be able to own a piece: I think of the leaf book of the Gutenberg Bible, 'A Noble Fragment,' that Gabriel Wells issued in 1921, and that now costs considerable" (email from August 20, 2019).

div1.head: VIII. Variorum edition
div1.p: All of these typographical, handwritten, spatial, and graphical differences, attributable to many hands, are represented in different ways in the variorum edition of the 1855 Leaves of Grass. We refer to this edition as a "variorum," repurposing an old term to describe an edition that gathers variants of a text—or of opinions about it—over time. This definition and the example of other variorum editions might suggest that all of the printed editions of Leaves, published over almost a half-century, should be represented—as they were, for instance, in the New York University Press Collected Writings variorum. Assembling all of the printed versions of Whitman's lines was not the goal of this project, though the Whitman Archive may in a future project take this approach to create a full variorum edition of the printed versions of Leaves of Grass.

With this undertaking, though, we wanted to emphasize the variation within and leading up to a single edition of Leaves of Grass. Our goal for this project is not completeness—although our effort to locate variants and early manuscripts has been as comprehensive as possible. Nor is the goal temporal mastery. Rather, we want to show the multiple temporalities incarnated by this first set of copies of Leaves of Grass—the manuscript and notebook beginnings, as well as the printed variants; the evolution of the reviews, as well as the ongoing fate of the copies. Our goal has been to create a dynamic edition that honors the specific format and circumstances of production associated with the hand-press first edition yet suggests to readers the many forms of instability and variation associated with this text—including the constant textual shufflings across the manuscript-print divide so characteristic of this poet's working process. We wanted to create an edition that vividly reveals to readers what Ed Folsom concluded over a decade ago: that, materially speaking, there is no such thing as the 1855 Leaves of Grass.

It is hard to understand the 1855 Leaves as a fixed manifestation produced at a single point in time for several reasons. The text and the spacing changed or were changed while the book was being printed. The printed copies of the Emerson letter and the reviews and extracts were added to the book at some point in its distribution. The text of the 1855 Leaves itself was printed and assembled unevenly, producing a situation in which possibly no two copies are alike. One surviving copy has no printed copyright statement, and two more have handwritten versions of it. It is possible that it took weeks, maybe months, to print the book; it is possible that Whitman was composing part of it at the last minute. The 1855 Leaves was in a state of more or less continuous composition and decomposition. The agents involved in that compositional process included Whitman, Andrew Rome and any other workers in the Rome print shop adjusting the forms and type and furniture of the set-up text, the engraver, the binders, Fowler & Wells and Horsell, George Betts and Abel Willmarth of the courts, and perhaps others. The creation of the text, then, is not a genetic matter alone, in part because Whitman never thought of the book as done, and in part because a teleological model centered around authorial agency does not tell the full story of the evolution and iteration of the 1855 Leaves of Grass. The goal of this edition, unlike a critical edition, is not to declare an ideal text or to evaluate whether variants are substantive or accidental. Instead it is to suggest that important information can be gleaned from all the many ways in which the copies differ, and to figure out how those differences might be represented in an electronic environment.

The base copy used for the main text of the variorum was a University of Iowa copy in binding A with the Tribune clipping with a transcription of the Emerson letter pasted to the front free endpaper. Page images of this copy are available at the top of each page in the main text of the variorum, and they are also viewable in a separate page viewer. Manuscript and notebook transcriptions are linked from the "Relations" tables next to lines and prose segments. Manuscript and notebook transcriptions are also linked from the "Related Manuscripts" boxes associated with the preface and each poem that appear at the right side of the screen. A key at the top of the variorum describes the different visual markers used to distinguish among variants and to mark related text. Clicking on a variant links to additional information, including images, the side-by-side image comparison viewer, a list of copies associated with each state, and the bibliography of copies. The reviews and extracts are linked from an annotation near the bottom of the main text. Links to both the reviews and extracts and the comparison viewer are also available in a sub-header bar at the top of the page. The main index page for the variorum links to the various parts of the edition as well as user instructions and short essays that provide additional context and background.

Information about the variations among individual copies has been derived from the 2005 census data and supplemented, where possible, by in-person examination of copies. Bindings and insertions and most of the textual and graphical variants had been identified in previous scholarship. Spatial and two additional textual variants were identified using two different collation strategies. The first involved printing a set of transparencies from digital images of the University of Iowa copy of the 1855 Leaves of Grass. These transparencies were then placed on top of the printed pages of several copies to collate the text. The second method of collation involved the use of the Hinman Collator at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. This method was used to compare the two copies in that collection, which were known to have different variant states.

Spatial variants, as noted in this introduction and in our editorial policy statement, are a limited selection from the total number of such variants. This subset is intended to give the user of the variorum some sense of the shifting type and the range of differences it created among the copies. Shifting type was not unusual in hand-press books, as a cursory look at books printed in Europe in earlier centuries would suggest. Relations among early manuscript and notebook text and printed lines and segments also do not represent a complete list of the possible relations. We have linked approximately 150 manuscripts and notebooks to specific sections of the text of the printed edition. For approximately 80 of these manuscripts and notebooks, we have a high certainty about the relationship.

For the purposes of the manuscript and notebook relations we have constructed the variorum around the insight that "for Whitman the line was the basic unit of his poetry."Folsom and Price, 32. We have attempted as systematically as possible to include early manuscript lines that are known to be drafts of printed lines that appeared in the 1855 Leaves of Grass. The process of associating manuscript and notebook antecedents with text in the printed versions of the poems and preface, however, presented a number of challenges. In the example of the "Lucifer" passage from the poem that would later be titled "The Sleepers," for instance, lines that Whitman included in early manuscripts made their way into other parts of the poem, or disappeared altogether. One manuscript section in the early notebook "Talbot Wilson" can only be tied to the "Lucifer" section by putting it next to other manuscripts, because the lines in it appeared in other manuscript versions of the passage, but not in the printed version.

In some cases we have based a relationship assertion on our judgment that a manuscript may have functioned as brainstorming for a section, and the relationship was plausible enough to justify creating a link. We have also included more distant relations, based on similarities of syntax or subject, that are less certain. In all cases, the goal has been to draw resources together and create interpretive possibilities, operating under the assumption that readers are very likely to see connections we have not seen, and that they are free to reject any connections that they judge to be invalid. We have also constructed the variorum fully aware that new manuscripts, new copies of the 1855 Leaves of Grass, and other potentially significant materials will come to light in the future. The flexible and extensible framework should allow us to incorporate such materials as they become available to us.

The user of the variorum should note that this is not intended to be a facsimile edition of the 1855 Leaves of Grass. The text and layout displayed in the variorum interface include a number of departures from the content and layout of that edition, including the addition of line numbers and of line breaks in the preface. Users wishing to see the text and layout as it appeared in a printed copy of the 1855 Leaves of Grass should consult the page images that appear as thumbnails in the main text of the variorum and in the page viewer. For more information about navigating the variorum, please see the instructions. For further discussion of our editorial rationale and our process of adding and encoding the relations, as well as the ways in which the variorum layout and text depart from the original layout of the printed books, please see our editorial policy statement for the variorum.

div1.head: IX. Conclusion
div1.p: Whitman began the poem he would later title "To Think of Time" with a meditation. "To think of time," he wrote: ". . . . to think through the retrospection, / To think of today . . and the ages continued henceforward." "Retrospection" can mean "a contemplation of the past," "a survey or review of past acts or events," or "the action of looking back."Oxford English Dictionary, "retrospection, n." We apply the term variorum to this edition of the 1855 Leaves of Grass to argue that understanding the complexities of the compositional and printing history of the first edition of Whitman's defining work demands a dense layering of manuscript and notebook antecedents with printed and other physical variations in remaining copies. This variorum represents only one edition of Leaves, but it is the first edition, and its bibliographic density—its manifold developmental layers—has until now remained largely unrecorded. Our variorum edition endeavors to draw the attention of the user to both temporal and spatial characteristics of the 1855 Leaves of Grass. It offers a way to linger over the specificities of a subset of printed copies and manuscripts, to think carefully about the "today" of the 1855 Leaves of Grass as one period within a longer retrospection—and to think through the retrospection itself, the act of reflecting on past textual actions and events that is necessary to the creation of any textual edition.

The overarching goal of the 1855 Leaves of Grass variorum, like that of other variorum editions, is to prompt its user to think of time.Perhaps this is true of editions more generally. As G. Thomas Tanselle has written, "the change-ability of texts over time is the basic fact that gave rise to such a field as textual criticism and has been the grounding for all editorial activity" ("Reflections"). It reflects intervals of time large and small, forms of revision both purposeful and accidental. The changes revealed in the evolution from manuscript to printed versions of lines and prose sections were sometimes incremental, and sometimes wholesale overhauls. They continued beyond this edition, in and out of manuscript, as Whitman continued revising toward and beyond the many future editions and issues of Leaves of Grass and other publications. They also continued in the myriad ways in which readers, collectors, and critics engaged with the distinct copies that comprise the first edition, demonstrating through their assertions of ownership and dedication, their acts of construction and destruction, the roles Whitman's writing and the books he helped to produce have continued to play in individual lives.

The 1855 Leaves of Grass, Folsom wrote in his Sesquicentennial essay, is "more than a text; it's an icon" (5). The variorum incorporates not just the evolving thoughts and language of the writer, but also the thoughts and analysis of critics and contemporaries, from Emerson's letter to the reviews and essays drawn from nineteenth-century periodicals. And, finally, it draws on a range of editorial projects and contributions, from printed editions of Whitman's prose manuscripts and notebooks to finding aids and the various materials available on the Walt Whitman Archive. This is the stuff of many years, and many hands. With it we hope to inspire readers to transform their imagination of what the 1855 Leaves of Grass is and what it encompasses. Rather than a book, or even a series of books, we present the 1855 Leaves as a nexus, an assemblage: a phenomenon rich and deep in both time and space, and an opening salvo to the longer story of Whitman's writing and its ongoing meaning and impact on the world.

div1.head: Credits and Acknowledgements
div1.p:
Co-directors: Ken Price and Ed Folsom
Editor: Nicole Gray
Associate Editors: Brett Barney, Stephanie Blalock, Brandon James O'Neil
Designers: Karin Dalziel, Jessica Dussault, Greg Tunink
Project Contributors: Matt Cohen, Caitlin Henry, Kevin McMullen

This project was made possible by a Scholarly Editions grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities (RQ-249901-16). We are grateful to have had the opportunity to inspect copies at Brevard College, Brown University, Duke University, Folger Library, Huntington Library, Library of Congress, New York Historical Society, New York Public Library, Princeton University, Providence Athenæum, Texas Tech University, University of Iowa, University of Kentucky, University of Nebraska, University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill, University of Texas, University of Virginia, and Wake Forest University. Special thanks to Kate Wodehouse at the Providence Athenæum, Wayne Hammond at Williams College, and Eric Frazier at the Library of Congress for scans related to the variorum, and to Emily Kader at the University of North Carolina for letting us use the Wilson Library's Hinman Collator. Thanks also to the librarians and archivists around the world who contributed data for the 2005 census of the surviving copies of the 1855 Leaves of Grass. Finally, we are grateful to Michael Winship, Randall McLeod, and audiences at the Society for Textual Scholarship annual conferences and the University of Pennsylvania for their helpful feedback about various parts of the project.
